newsitem.title: CUBA: Pope's Cuba visit should boost church - cardinal.
newsitem.headline: Pope's Cuba visit should boost church - cardinal.

text.p: Pope John Paul's visit to Cuba next year should boost the Roman Catholic Church locally and help it obtain a wider role on the communist-ruled island, a visiting cardinal said on Monday.

Cardinal Camillo Ruini, president of Italy's bishops' conference, told reporters at the end of a four-day visit that plans for the papal trip were the focus of a long and "very interesting" talk he had on Friday with President Fidel Castro.
Castro had been interested in how papal visits were organised, Ruini said.

Ruini announced the date of the Pontiff's trip to Cuba -- the second half of January 1998 -- during a mass in Havana on Friday. The trip was agreed at a landmark first meeting between the Pope and Castro last November at the Vatican, but a date had not been set.
The Vatican meeting marked a clear improvement in recent months in ties between the communist authorities and the church in Cuba.
Ruini, describing the Cuban chuch as very alive, said the papal visit should give it a further boost, as well as serving to "widen the margins of liberty that the church has in Cuba."
He said it was clear the Cuban people were anxious to see the Pontiff.
